facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 969 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 969 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 13, 1959

facts.text: Appeal is from the award dated November 13, 1959 of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam in specified Sub-References.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 13, 1959 of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam in Sub-References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

facts.text: Award published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960 via Notification No. 361/55/690 dated December 29, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J. This appeal is brought, by special leave,. against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam, published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960, vide Assam Government Notification No. 361/55/690 dated December 29, 1959

facts.text: During June 1951 to March 1953, entire tea industry in Cachar district of Assam faced unusual economic crisis.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave,. against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam, published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960, vide Assam Government Notification No. 361/55/690 dated December 29, 1959, in References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958. During the period from June, 1951 to March, 1953 the entire tea industry in the Cachar district of Assam was subject to an unusual economic crisis.

facts.text: Steep rise in cost of production due to increase of wages and introduction of subsidised rations.

anchor.surface_text: During the period from June, 1951 to March, 1953 the entire tea industry in the Cachar district of Assam was subject to an unusual economic crisis. There was a steep rise in the companyt of production due to increase of wages and introduction of subsidised rations.

facts.text: In October 1949, Tripartite Conference held at Silchar decided nearly 20 Tea Estates uneconomic and allowed conversion of food concessions into cash at 0-4-6 per head per day.

anchor.surface_text: In October, 1949, a Tripartite Conference was held at Silchar and it was decided in this Conference that nearly 20 Tea Estates had become uneconomic and should be allowed to companyvert food companycessions into cash at the rate of 0-4-6 per 34 6 head per day.

facts.text: Need for re-adjustment of labour force recognised in October 1949 Tripartite Conference.

anchor.surface_text: The need for re-adjustment of labour force was also recognised in this Conference.

facts.text: On February 12, 1949, Ad hoc Committee appointed, submitted report on September 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The financial position of the Tea Estates however companytinued to cause anxiety to the Government. On February 12, 1949, an Ad hoc Committee was appointed which submitted its report on September 13, 1950.

facts.text: Ad hoc Committee found tea industry unable to bear burden of subsidised food-stuffs, considerable increase in production cost, compelled to borrow more, yield 7 mds per acre vs economic min 8 mds per acre.

anchor.surface_text: In this report the Committee stressed the inability of the tea industry to bear the burden of subsidised food-stuffs. The Committee further found that the increase in production companyt was companysiderable and the tea estates were companypelled to borrow more money and the Scheduled Banks were finding it difficult to meet the demand. The Committee found that the yield of tea in Cachar district was 7 mds. per acre and in its view the absolute minimum yield which companyld be economic in Cachar was 8 mds. per acre.

facts.text: Cachar Plantation Committee constituted on April 4, 1950, report submitted January 4, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the critical companydition of the tea industry in Cachar another Committee named as The Cachar Plantation Committee was companystituted on April 4, 1.950. The report of the Committee was submitted on January 4, 1951.

facts.text: Cachar Plantation Committee recommended abandonment of uneconomic areas, alternative employment or wet land to surplus labour, seven annas conversion rate per day in lieu of food concession, Government supply foodgrains at controlled rates.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee recommended abandonment of uneconomic areas under tea and suggested offer of alternative employment to the surplus labour or provision of whet land, if available. The Committee also recommended a seven annas companyversion rate per day in lieu of food companycession for all estates and it was proposed that Gov- ernment should undertake to supply foodgrains to tea estates at companytrolled wholesale rates.

facts.text: In 1951 sudden recession in world price of tea, fluctuations from mid June 1951, rapid decline November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1 951 there was a sudden recession in the world price of tea. Fluctuations companymenced in the middle of June, 1 951 and there was a rather rapid decline in prices of tea in November, 1951.

facts.text: Cachar tea prices fell from 1-10-1 per lb on October 30, 1951 to 1-2-11 per lb on March 17, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Cachar prices came down from 1-10-1 per lb. on October 30, 1951 to 1-2-11 per lb. on March 17, 1952.

facts.text: Notification under Minimum Wages Act dated March 11, 1952 raising wages substantially.

anchor.surface_text: To add to the difficulties of the tea industry there was a numberification under the Minimum Wages Act dated March 11, 1952 raising wages of labour substantially.

facts.text: By January 22, 1953, 82 out of 111 gardens in Cachar district had closed down.

anchor.surface_text: Before the team companycluded its investigation the situation had taken a critical turn and the tea industry in Cachar was on the verge of a total companylapse. By January 22, 1953, 82 out of Ill gardens in Cachar district had closed down.

facts.text: Revised notification dated February 9, 1953 under Minimum Wages Act for Cachar and uneconomic Assam Valley estates: suspension of food concessions, temporary raise in dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance, of the recommendation of the Committee there was a revised numberi- fication dated February 9, 1953, under the Minimum Wages Act with regard to all the tea estates in the district of Cachar and the uneconomic tea estates in the Assam Valley. The numberification provided that there shall be numberissue of food- stuffs at companycessional rates and numbercash companypensation as such in lieu thereof. But with a view to mitigate the hardship of labour due to suspension of food companycessions, the existing dearness allowance was raised temporarily for all Cachar tea estates at the rate of one anna for adults and six pies for minors for each working day.

facts.text: After revised notification, economic condition improved, many estates refunctioned, retrenched workmen taken back or provided alternative employment.

anchor.surface_text: After the issue of the revised numberification the economic companydition of the tea estates improved and many tea estates started refunctioning. Many of the workmen who were retrenched were taken back in employment and others were provided alternative employment in tea estates outside Cachar district in the Assam Valley district or elsewhere.

facts.text: Union claimed no genuine crisis justifying retrenchment/lay-off, crisis manipulated by management to revise min wage notif and crush union, entitled to compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Cachar Chah Sramik Union  hereinafter called -the Union  before the Industrial Tribunal was that there was numbergenuine crisis which companyld justify retrenchment, lay off or even reduction of working days in a week. According to the Union the financial crisis was manipulated by the management because of the numberification under the Minimum Wages Act issued in March, 1952. The object of the management was to force the Government to revise that numberification and at the same ,time to crush the growing trade union movement.

facts.text: Management contended real sudden financial crisis compelled reduction of working days and retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite view was put forward by the management and it was companytended on its behalf that it was companypelled to reduce the number of working days and, in some cases, to resort to retrenchment because there was a real and sudden financial crisis in the industry and the industry companyld number be run with profit without resort to these measures.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held financial crisis genuine, not manipulated, management entitled to lay off under cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii) and retrench under cl. 9 of Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these rival companytentions the Industrial Tribunal held, in the first place, that the financial crisis was genuine and was number a result of any manipulation and that the management was entitled under cl. 8 a  i  and  iii  of the Standing Orders to lay off the workmen for an indefinite period. The Tribunal further held that the management was also entitled to retrench workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded reasonable compensation at one week's pay for every four months of unemployment, amenities like khet land, housing, medical equal to one week's wages.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal companysidered that even if the lay off and retrenchment were bona fide and justified, the workmen were entitled to a reasonable companypensation and fixed the quantum of companypensation at the rate of one weeks pay for every four months of unemployment. Finally the Tribunal held that the provision of khet land and other amenities like housing and medical facilities available to the workmen should be taken to adequately represent one weeks wages.

facts.text: Tribunal examined each individual garden and awarded compensation in some cases, refused in others.

anchor.surface_text: After laying down these principles the Industrial Tribunal examined the case of each individual garden and awarded companypensation in some cases while refusing to grant any companypensation in others.

facts.text: Supreme Court found economic crisis real, caused by reasons beyond control of management, sudden slump covered by 'other causes beyond his control' in cl. 8(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has also found that the economic crisis of the tea industry in Cachar region was real and was caused by reasons beyond the companytrol of the management of the tea estates. In our opinion, the last part of cl. 8 a  i  which refers to other causes beyond his companytrol would companyer a case of sudden slump in the world market and the companysequent financial difficulties of the tea estates.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Tribunal's finding of no victimisation, unfair labour practice or mala fides in closing gardens or retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that there was numbervictimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrench- ment.

facts.text: Supreme Court held lay off justified under cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii), retrenchment under cl. 9, compensation quantum reasonable, no error in Tribunal's estimate, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that there is numbermerit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 13, 1959 of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam in Sub-References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

This appeal is brought, by special leave,. against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam, published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960, vide Assam Government Notification No. 361/55/690 dated December 29, 1959, in References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

issues.text: Whether the financial crisis in the tea industry was genuine and not a result of manipulation by the management?

anchor.surface_text: short working hours and retrenchment were unfair labour practice. The Union claimed compensation on the ground that the measures taken by the management were wholly unjustified. It was alternatively contended that even if the measures were justified, the workmen were entitled to compensation on account of involuntary unemployment which they had suffered for no fault of theirs.

issues.text: Whether the management was entitled under cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii) of the Standing Orders to lay off the workmen for an indefinite period due to the financial crisis?

anchor.surface_text: entitled under cl. 8 a i and iii of the Standing Orders to lay off the workmen for an indefinite period. The Tribunal further held that the management was also entitled to retrench workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders. The Tribunal considered that even if the lay off and retrenchment were bona fide and justified, the workmen were entitled to a reasonable compensation and fixed the quantum of compensation at the rate of one weeks pay for every four months of unemployment.

issues.text: Whether the management was entitled to retrench workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders?

anchor.surface_text: retrench workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders. The Tribunal considered that even if the lay off and retrenchment were bona fide and justified, the workmen were entitled to a reasonable compensation and fixed the quantum of compensation at the rate of one weeks pay for every four months of unemployment. Finally the Tribunal held that the provision of khet land and other amenities like housing and medical facilities available to the workmen should be taken to adequately represent one weeks wages.

issues.text: Whether there was victimisation, unfair labour practice or mala fides by the management in closing the gardens or retrenching workmen?

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that there was no victimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrench- ment. Mr. Aggarwala on behalf of the appellant did not challenge the finding of the Tribunal on this point,

issues.text: Whether the workmen were entitled to retrenchment compensation strictly according to the scale in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act?

anchor.surface_text: entitled to payment of compensation according to the scale laid down in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act. It was conceded by learned Counsel that Ch. VA which contains s. 25F came into force on October 24, 1953 by amending Act 43 of 1953 and the retrenchment in the present case was effected long before that date.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal's quantum of compensation (one week's wages for every four months of unemployment), accounting for amenities like khet land, housing and medical facilities, was adequate?

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Tribunal has estimated the amount of compensation as one weeks wages for every four months of unemployment and it is not shown on behalf of the appellant that in making this estimate the Tribunal has committed any error of law or applied any wrong principle.

issues.text: Whether the ex gratia payments to workmen subjected to short hours of work sufficiently compensated for their loss of wages?

anchor.surface_text: As regards the workmen who were subjected to short hours of work, the Tribunal has observed that they have been granted ex gratia payments which were, in several cases in excess of the total loss of wages by reason of the revision of the daily wages under the notification of February 9, 1953 under the Minimum Wages Act.

arguments.claim: There was no genuine crisis which could justify retrenchment, lay off or reduction of working days; the financial crisis was manipulated by management to force revision of Minimum Wages notification and crush the union; introduction of short hours and retrenchment were unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Cachar Chah Sramik Union  hereinafter called -the Union  before the Industrial Tribunal was that there was no genuine crisis which could justify retrenchment, lay off or even reduction of working days in a week. According to the Union the financial crisis was manipulated by the management because of the notification under the Minimum Wages Act issued in March, 1952. The object of the management was to force the Government to revise that notification and at the same ,time to crush the growing trade union movement. It was contended that the introduction of short working hours and retrenchment were unfair labour practice.

arguments.claim: Cl. 8(a) has no application; financial difficulty not beyond control; cannot lay off under this clause. (Citing Dewan Tea Estate)

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant-Union Mr. Aggarwala submitted, in the, first place, that cl. 8 a  of the Standing Orders had no application to the present case and the Tribunal was not justified in holding that the financial difficulty facing the tea estates was a matter beyond the control of the management, and the workmen could not, therefore, be laid off by the management under this clause. ... In support of this argument Mr. Aggarwala referred to the decision of this Court in Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ork or both without numberice. In cases where workmen are laid off for short periods on account of failure of plant or a temporary curtailment of prod

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts different from Dewan (no sudden slump there); cl.8(a)(i) 'other causes beyond control' covers sudden world market slump and financial crisis.

arguments.claim: Sudden slump in tea prices and financial crisis covered by 'other causes beyond his control' in cl.8(a)(i); lay-off justified under cl.8(a)(i)&(iii).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has also found that the economic crisis of the tea industry in Cachar region was real and was caused by reasons beyond the control of the management of the tea estates. In our opinion, the last part of cl. 8 a  i  which refers to other causes beyond his control would cover a case of sudden slump in the world market and the consequent financial difficulties of the tea estates.

There is substance in the argument... See The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen...

holdings.text: The economic crisis of the tea industry in Cachar region was real and was caused by reasons beyond the control of the management of the tea estates.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has also found that the economic crisis of the tea industry in Cachar region was real and was caused by reasons beyond the control of the management of the tea estates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds Tribunal's factual finding based on evidence of sudden slump, price decline, and industry reports; distinguishes from Dewan Tea Estate where no sudden slump.

holdings.text: The last part of cl. 8(a)(i) which refers to other causes beyond his control would cover a case of sudden slump in the world market and the consequent financial difficulties of the tea estates.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the last part of cl. 8 a i which refers to other causes beyond his control would cover a case of sudden slump in the world market and the consequent financial difficulties of the tea estates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of clause extends to unforeseen market slump beyond management control, unlike routine financial difficulties.

holdings.text: The lay off in the present case was justified by cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii) of the Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the lay off in the present case was justified by cl. 8 a i and iii of the Standing Orders and the argument of Mr. Aggarwala on this aspect of the case is not warranted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies clauses to accepted facts of crisis beyond control.

holdings.text: The management had the additional power of retrenching workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: As regards retrenchment, we are satisfied that the management had also the additional power of retrenching workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders which reads as follows...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of clause 9 permitting termination with notice or pay in lieu.

holdings.text: There was no victimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that there was no victimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrench- ment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal's finding, unchallenged by petitioner; evidence supports no mala fides.

holdings.text: The principle embodied in s. 25F should be applied even though not strictly applicable as retrenchment pre-dated its enforcement; Tribunals exercised discretion pre-enactment.

anchor.surface_text: the workmen were entitled to payment of compensation according to the scale laid down in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act. It was conceded by learned Counsel that Ch. VA which contains s. 25F came into force on October 24, 1953...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ch. VA codified pre-existing Tribunal practice; strict scale not mandatory but principle of compensation applies.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's estimate of one week's wages for every four months of unemployment was adequate compensation; no error of law or wrong principle applied.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Tribunal has estimated the amount of compensation as one weeks wages for every four months of unemployment and it is not shown on behalf of the appellant that in making this estimate the Tribunal has committed any error of law...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-s.25F discretion allowed consideration of factors; Tribunal's quantum reasonable.

holdings.text: The value of amenities like khet land, housing, medical facilities roughly equal to one week's wages for every four months; no additional cash compensation due apart from notice pay.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal has stated in para 135 of the Award that the amenities granted to them included undisturbed possession of residential quarters and khet lands... the value of these concessions would be roughly equal to one weeks wages...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's rough evaluation of non-cash benefits offsets cash claim.

holdings.text: Ex gratia payments to workmen on short hours sufficient, often in excess of wage loss due to revised wages; short hours normal even in normal times.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the workmen who were subjected to short hours of work, the Tribunal has observed that they have been granted ex gratia payments which were, in several cases in excess of the total loss of wages...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows payments exceeded losses post-revision; undisputed normality of short hours.

holdings.text: There is no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that there is no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings uphold Tribunal award in full.

precedents.citation: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management 1

anchor.surface_text: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management 1 . But the ratio of that decision has no application to the present case in which the material facts are different. In Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management 1  there was numbersudden slump in the price of tea but there was difficulty experienced by the management in obtaining financial facilities from banks. It was an individual case of management experiencing financial diffi- culty, and it was, therefore, held by this Court that the stoppage of financial assistance will number fall within the phrase stoppage of power or supply in cl. 8 a  i  of the Standing Orders.

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management
precedents.cited_proposition: financial difficulty due to stoppage of financial assistance from banks does not constitute 'stoppage of power or supply' or 'other causes beyond his control' under cl. 8(a)(i) of the Standing Orders
precedents.cited_holding: the stoppage of financial assistance will number fall within the phrase stoppage of power or supply in cl. 8 a  i  of the Standing Orders

precedents.citation: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management 1

anchor.surface_text: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management 1  there was numbersudden slump in the price of tea but there was difficulty experienced by the management in obtaining financial facilities from banks. It was an individual case of management experiencing financial diffi- culty, and it was, therefore, held by this Court that the stoppage of financial assistance will number fall within the phrase stoppage of power or supply in cl. 8 a  i  of the Standing Orders. It was also pointed out in that case that there was numberevidence produced on behalf of the management to substantiate its plea of number-availability of finance.

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management
precedents.cited_proposition: lack of evidence to show financial difficulty was beyond management's control and stoppage of bank finance not covered by standing orders clause
precedents.cited_holding: there was numberevidence produced on behalf of the management to substantiate its plea of number-availability of finance. precedents.citation: The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen and another 1

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen and another 1 . There is substance in the argument put forward on behalf of the appellant and the Tribunal has also applied this principle in granting companypensation to the retrenched workmen even though the case was number attracted by s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act. But the Tribunal has taken the view that one weeks wages for every four months of unemployment was adequate companypensation. The companytention of the appellant is that the companypensation should have been awarded on the scale laid down in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act.

precedents.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: legislature by enacting Ch. VA merely recognised the pre-existing practice of Labour Tribunals awarding compensation on retrenchment

precedents.citation: The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen, and another 1

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen, and another 1 , Industrial Tribunals had been awarding companypensation even before the enactment of s. 25F but there was numberuniformity or certainty in the matter and in determining the, amount of companypensation the Tribunals companysidered a variety of relevant factors. It is manifest that in determining the amount of companypensation the Tribunals exercised companyplete discretion and took into, account whatever factors they companysidered relevant. In the present case, the Tribunal has estimated the amount of companypensation as one weeks wages for every four months of unemployment and it is number shown on behalf of the appellant that in making this estimate the Tribunal has companymitted any error of law or applied any wrong principle.

precedents.cited_proposition: before s. 25F, tribunals awarded retrenchment compensation without uniformity, considering various factors in their discretion
precedents.cited_holding: Industrial Tribunals had been awarding companypensation even before the enactment of s. 25F but there was numberuniformity or certainty in the matter and in determining the amount of companypensation the Tribunals companysidered a variety of relevant factors
